Al menos, aquellos cuyos cuerpos son llevados ante la secuoya y se les concede el Rito del Recuerdo, realizado por la {@book Voice of Memory|TDCSR|3|Ouestra, the Voice of Memory} y sus discípulos, tienen sus recuerdos preservados y añadidos al colectivo. Casi todos los {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} en {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} reciben este rito, y un gran número de {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} que viven en otros lugares escriben en sus testamentos que deben someterse al rito después de su muerte.

Mechas de luz violeta revolotean por las antiguas ramas de la secuoya, y se sabe que aquellos que miran de cerca en sus centros vislumbran épocas pasadas, problemas presentes y cosas que aún pueden ser. La gran secuoya y sus espíritus son vigilados y atendidos por los Tejedores de Sueños, {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} que han dedicado su vida de vigilia y de sueño a la protección de su patrimonio. Unos quinientos Tejedores de Sueños y cinco mil eruditos, comerciantes y otros {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} llaman a este distrito su hogar.

Los {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} son una cultura obsesionada con la tradición y el pasado. Como tal, los Tejedores de Sueños se encuentran entre las facciones más respetadas dentro del {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. Su líder, el {@book Ouestra, the Voice of Memory|TDCSR|3|Ouestra, the Voice of Memory}, es igualmente el más venerado y poderoso socialmente del {@book Wardens|TDCSR|3|Wardens of Syngorn}.

entries.name: Beryl Keep
entries: Este distrito-fortaleza alberga el poderío marcial de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. Situado en una colina al noroeste de la ciudad, gruesos muros de berilo verde hoja separan el distrito del resto de la ciudad. Dentro de estos muros hay hileras de barracones, campos de tiro con arco, cámaras de trance, forjas, comedores y todo lo necesario para entrenar a un ejército de {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} longevos. En el extremo noroeste del distrito se encuentra la propia Fortaleza de Berilo. La casi inexpugnable fortaleza demuestra el dicho de que hasta lo más utilitario de los elfos es hermoso a los ojos de los mortales. Seis eucaliptos de edad desconocida marcan los límites de la fortaleza, y entre ellos crece una gruesa cortina de corteza de hierro. Un denso dosel de impenetrable steelfern forma su techo. La leyenda dice que cuando {@book Syngorn's|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} la necesidad es mayor, los seis antiguos eucaliptos que custodian el torreón se arrancan y marchan como poderosos {@creature treant|MM|treants} para defender la ciudad.

La Fortaleza de Beryl está comandada por {@book Verdant Lord Celindar|TDCSR|3|Verdant Lord Celindar}, {@book Syngorn's|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} maestro estratega. Posee un {@item crystal ball} de {@spell true seeing} dentro de su sala de guerra, que puede utilizar para {@spell scrying|PHB|scry} sobre cualquier parte del {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse} y para atravesar cualquier ilusión. Desde este punto de vista, dirige sus fuerzas como un maestro de ajedrez, siempre un paso por delante de las amenazas dentro del bosque encantado. Hasta ahora, el {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} permanece a salvo porque sus enemigos son salvajes y están desorganizados. Si se unificaran, el poder de la Guardia Verdant sería realmente puesto a prueba.

Los ejércitos del {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} tienen unos cinco mil {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} efectivos, aunque sólo unos tres mil están dentro de este distrito en todo momento. El resto están estacionados en puestos de avanzada dentro del {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse} y el Reino de los Fey.

entries.name: Tarn Ward
entries: {@book Syngorn's|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} El distrito central es un tranquilo barrio comercial que rodea el lago Ywynnlas y está dividido por los canales que lo alimentan. Desde el amanecer hasta el atardecer, aquí no se llevan a cabo negocios, salvo el servicio de comida en las casas públicas y las camas en las posadas. Durante las horas de luz, {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} socializan, juegan, cantan canciones, escriben poesía, pintan grandes obras de arte y meditan aquí. {@book Elves|TDCSR|5|elves} son longevos, y si la mitad del día no se dedica a la paz y a la superación personal, se piensa que el día ha sido realmente desperdiciado, por muy productivo que se haya sido en materia de negocios.

Al anochecer, sin embargo, el Barrio del Tarn cambia. El Barrio de Tarn se abre al salir la luna, iluminado sólo por los cielos y por faroles mágicos y flotantes. Las calles son silenciosas, salvo por el etéreo canto de los elfos que guía a los que saben escuchar por las calles. Los {@book Elves|TDCSR|5|elves} y los semielfos criados en {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} conocen este lenguaje musical, pero los que no están familiarizados con él deben utilizar un hechizo {@spell comprehend languages} para seguir la melodía. Cuando el río de sonido guía a un cliente hasta un vendedor, hablan en voz baja {@language Elvish}, como un público que susurra en el teatro.

La mayoría de las tiendas a lo largo de la Ruta del Tarn están afiliadas a uno de los tres gremios -el Gremio de Hechiceros, la Alianza de Artesanos Elfos o la Hermandad Mithral- y el astuto {@book Guildrunner Rawndel|TDCSR|3|Guildrunner Rawndel} está a la cabeza de los tres. El guardián de este distrito, Rawndel, vive en un {@spell Mordenkainen's Magnificent Mansion|PHB|magnificent mansion} permanente con una fachada adornada con espléndidos grotescos feéricos, y es respetado por los comerciantes elfos y los nobles por igual. Al {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} no parece importarle su monopolio sobre el comercio de Thoroughfare, ya que sus vidas no se han visto muy afectadas, pero al {@book High Warden Tirelda|TDCSR|3|High Warden Tirelda} le preocupan las consecuencias a largo plazo del comportamiento ávido de poder de Rawndel.

entries.name: Syngornian Goods
entries: Todos los bienes básicos se pueden comprar en {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} al doble de su coste habitual. Estos bienes, sin embargo, son de fina factura élfica. {@item +1 weapon|DMG|Weapons have a +1 bonus to damage rolls}, {@filter horses and other mounts|items|source=null|Type=Mount} aumentan su velocidad de movimiento en 10 pies, y otros objetos poseen una belleza sobrenatural y una durabilidad preternatural. Todos los objetos mágicos comunes se pueden encontrar fácilmente aquí, y cualquier objeto mágico poco común tiene un {@chance 50||Uncommon Item|You find the item!|The item is nowhere to be found.} de posibilidades de encontrarse aquí en los numerosos puestos del mercado del barrio. Encontrar objetos mágicos de mayor rareza requiere que el personaje haga un chequeo de {@dc 21} Carisma ({@skill Investigation}) para encontrar un objeto raro, o un chequeo de {@dc 25} ({@skill Investigation}) para encontrar un objeto muy raro. Estos objetos rara vez están a la venta, y sólo pueden ser objeto de trueque, normalmente completando una búsqueda peligrosa para la persona que los posee.

entries.name: Emerald Citadel
entries: El gran palacio de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} se alza en lo alto del norte de la ciudad, un poderoso castillo de mármol blanco descolorido, ahora cubierto de hiedra trepadora y de plantas que brotan. Al ser el punto más alto de la ciudad, que se inclina gradualmente, sus agujas con puntas de esmeralda pueden verse desde cualquier lugar. Los visitantes de la ciudadela suben primero una gran escalera, curvada como un río de mármol que fluye, antes de llegar a sus puertas de bronce. La Guardia Verdant protege agresivamente la entrada principal del castillo, rechazando a cualquier plebeyo que no tenga una invitación al palacio marcada con el sello del Alto Guardián. {@book High Warden Tirelda's|TDCSR|3|High Warden Tirelda} mayordomo monocular, un elfo de pelo plateado llamado Ibbimas, hace de pantalla a todos los suplicantes del Alto Guardián.

Los altos techos abovedados del palacio se apoyan en pilares de mármol brillante tallados con la imagen de altos olmos, de modo que los techos son un dosel de piedra pulida. Hermosos retratos y bustos del pasado {@book Wardens|TDCSR|3|Wardens of Syngorn} se alinean en las paredes, junto con opulentos tapices de Yenlara y la creación de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. La ciudadela consta de cuatro niveles principales. Los niveles del sótano albergan las mazmorras del castillo, así como grandes bóvedas que contienen fabulosos tesoros, artefactos históricos y regalos exagerados, estos últimos entregados por emisarios que no saben cómo presentar un regalo lo suficientemente fino para un monarca elfo. La primera planta alberga exuberantes aposentos para embajadores y dignatarios visitantes. Las cámaras del segundo piso están dedicadas a los asuntos de estado, incluida la sala del trono del Alto Gobernador. Las torres situadas sobre la ciudadela contienen los estudios y los aposentos de la Alta Alcaide y su familia.

entries.title: Art Credit: {@link Kent Davis|http://artstation.com/idrawbagman}
entries.altText: An emerald peaked stone citadel stands grandly above a beautiful, sylvan stone path. It is surrounded by a grand white and gold gate within a thick forest canopy, several cloaked individuals guard the gate as another figure approaches.

entries.name: Feygrove
entries: Una casa solariega en el sur {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, que en su día fue espléndida, está ahora completamente cubierta de vegetación. Enormes moreras brotan en ángulos extraños por las ventanas y a través de los frontones, y las luces de hadas bailan alrededor de la casa a todas las horas del día. Cuando {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} regresó del Reino de los Fey después de la derrota de {@book Conclave's|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}, los {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} trajeron involuntariamente un poco del Reino de los Fey con ellos. Un número de criaturas feéricas se deslizó a través de una puerta del Reino Fey a Exandria, luego se escabulló a través de {@book Syngorn's|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} las defensas y se instaló en la mansión de una noble elfa llamada Lady Ladri Il'shavfa. Ella ha intentado durante años recuperar su hogar, pero incluso la paciencia del {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} se agota; los feys son simplemente demasiado numerosos y demasiado tenaces para ser expulsados definitivamente.

Sin embargo, los intrusos feéricos se divierten como nunca. Lejos de limitarse a organizar fiestas nocturnas -aunque también lo hacen-, han convertido la mansión Il'shavfa en un lugar donde experimentar con la nueva magia salvaje. Su líder, un príncipe {@creature pixie} llamado Windybranch, ha encontrado un gran placer en plantar extrañas plantas feéricas en la casa y ver cómo se integran con la mansión. La casa es ahora una cosa viva, que respira y piensa, ¡un nuevo amigo para los fey! Mantiene al {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} fuera y es un gran conversador. ¡Para los fey, este arreglo no tiene inconvenientes! Las hadas han bautizado esta mansión con el nombre del Archfey que les permitió entrar por primera vez en la ciudad. Para ellas, su nuevo hogar es la Logia de Artagan (y se dice que el {@deity The Traveler|Exandria|TDCSR|Archfey Artagan} se aloja ocasionalmente entre sus muros cuando visita Tal'Dorei).

Desde que el Feygrove fue "fundado" por primera vez hace más de veinte años, los fey se han desbordado de la Mansión Il'shavfa y han convertido todo un distrito de la ciudad en su hogar. A estas alturas, sólo los más obstinados de la nobleza élfica siguen quejándose de "la amenaza fey" en su seno. La mayoría de los residentes {@book Syngorn's|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} están encantados de tener un distrito lleno de fey, incluso si esto provoca que el extremo sur de la ciudad sea un poco más caótico de lo habitual. Los fey de aquí parecen tener un corazón bondadoso, y su caos rara vez cruza la línea de las bromas maliciosas hacia la crueldad.

entries.name: Reverie Walks
entries: El centro artístico y espiritual de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} es un sinuoso laberinto de árboles vivos y piedras. Los {@book Elves|TDCSR|5|elves} que buscan un viaje de meditación de un día (o de varios días) pueden deambular por los Paseos del Ensueño, entrando en un estado de trance mientras lo hacen. Los que buscan la verdadera iluminación pueden dedicar años de su vida casi inmortal a vagar por el laberinto siempre cambiante, encontrando la paz en el aislamiento o en busca de la Piedra del {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} en el centro del laberinto. Un monje elfo llamado Lyssev Sorveline ha caminado por el laberinto durante quinientos años, buscando respuestas a preguntas que ni siquiera los dioses conocen. Algunos {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} dejan regalos de comida para el Errante dentro del laberinto, permitiéndole continuar su meditación eterna en paz.

Ningún guardián domina los Paseos del Ensueño. La leyenda sostiene que las piedras y los árboles vivos que recorren el laberinto son devotos del {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} que juraron ser los guardianes eternos de su dios.

entries.name: Points of Interest
entries: {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} tiene una serie de puntos de referencia famosos. Están codificados en el mapa de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}.

entries.title: The City of Syngorn
entries.altText: A map of the elven city of Syngorn showing the neighborhoods and wards that surround Lake Ywnnlas.

entries: {@note Art Credit: {@link Andy Law|http://artstation.com/andylaw1}}

entries.name: 1. Elvencraft Alliance Guildhall
entries: La Alianza Elvencraft es supuestamente el gremio más antiguo de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. Se encargan de crear obras de arte que difunden la cultura del {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} a lo largo y ancho del Tal'Dorei. Las salas delanteras de su gremio son un museo de finas artesanías élficas de épocas pasadas, y están abiertas a todos los que deseen apreciar el {@book Syngorn's|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} patrimonio cultural.

entries.name: 2. Guildrunner's Mansion
entries: {@book Guildrunner Rawndel|TDCSR|3|Guildrunner Rawndel}, guardián del pabellón de Tarn, tiene su hogar en un {@spell Mordenkainen's Magnificent Mansion|PHB|magnificent mansion} permanente. Su exterior es una magnífica fachada de piedra y estatuas feéricas, pero si uno mirara dentro, lo encontraría completamente vacío. La puerta, que está constantemente cerrada para todos excepto para el Guildrunner y sus invitados, es en realidad un portal a un espacio extradimensional que contiene una mansión de belleza y lujo sobrenaturales.

entries.name: 3. Mithral Fellowship Guildhall
entries: Los maestros metalúrgicos y herreros de la Hermandad Mithral se encargan de armar a la Guardia Verde y a los ejércitos de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. En tiempos de paz, dedican su talento a crear objetos de belleza a partir del metal y las joyas, a veces en colaboración con los artistas de la Alianza de Artesanos Elfos. Debido a su implicación militar, sólo los miembros autorizados de la comunidad están autorizados a entrar en su sala de reuniones.

entries.name: 4. One Thousand Steps
entries: Esta escalera sinuosa es la única forma de entrar o salir del {@book Memory Ward|TDCSR|4|Memory Ward}. Cada peldaño lleva inscrita una antigua expresión élfica, un aforismo o una pregunta filosófica imposible. A cualquiera que entre en el {@book Memory Ward|TDCSR|4|Memory Ward} se le dice que lea el aforismo en el primer escalón y que reflexione sobre él todo el tiempo que suba la escalera. Si encuentra paz en su respuesta, debe leer la inscripción del segundo escalón en su siguiente viaje, y así sucesivamente. Son pocos, incluso entre el {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, los que han reflexionado satisfactoriamente sobre las inscripciones de todos los peldaños.

entries.name: 5. Spires of Yurek
entries: Caminos bordeados de dormitorios y vendedores irradian desde las ramas de la Secuoya del Recuerdo hasta los muros de la {@book Memory Ward|TDCSR|4|Memory Ward}, proporcionando lo esencial no sólo para los Tejedores de Sueños, sino para los eruditos elfos que enseñan, estudian y experimentan con la magia dentro de las Espiras de Yurek. Esta academia lleva el nombre de {@book Yurek Windkeeper|TDCSR|Enchanter Yurek Windkeeper}, fundadora del {@book Arcana Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical} y consejera personal de la propia {@book Voice of Memory|TDCSR|3|Ouestra, the Voice of Memory}. La escuela es pequeña comparada con el magnífico {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, pero sus siete torres de mármol no son menos impresionantes. Los personajes que visitan las Espiras de Yurek pueden aprender cualquier hecho histórico estudiando sus tomos durante una hora y haciendo después un chequeo exitoso de Inteligencia ({@dc 20}). Incluso pueden descubrir pistas sobre secretos perdidos hace mucho tiempo si completan un día de estudio y luego tienen éxito en un chequeo de {@dc 25} Inteligencia ({@skill History}). Aquí se inventan constantemente nuevos hechizos, y en las bibliotecas se pueden encontrar innumerables tomos llenos de hechizos antiguos.

entries.name: 6. Tower of Moonlight
entries: La mayoría de los visitantes de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} dudan de que {@book Ouestra, the Voice of Memory|TDCSR|3|Ouestra, the Voice of Memory}, realmente habite en una torre de luz de luna. Es la verdad. Su torre no existe bajo la luz del sol, y entonces aparece como un pilar semisólido del brillo plateado de Catha, ocasionalmente veteado por líneas de la luz rojiza de Ruidus cuando la luna más pequeña está llena. Se supone que su interior nunca ha sido visto por nadie más que por el otro {@book Wardens of Syngorn|TDCSR|3|Wardens of Syngorn}, y circulan mil rumores por todo el reino sobre las maravillas mágicas y divinas que debe contener.

entries.name: 7. Spellbenders' Guildhall
entries: El {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse} está saturado de magia. Las energías ley que inundan el bosque verde facilitan a los arcanistas la creación de obras de hechicería por sí mismos, cuando en otras tierras se necesitaría media docena de magos trabajando en conjunto. Muchos de los magos de mayor confianza son miembros de los Hechiceros, un gremio dedicado a crear nuevos hechizos y utilizarlos para crear obras de arte, defender su tierra natal y mejorar la vida de sus pueblos. A su cofradía sólo pueden acceder aquellos con el permiso expreso de {@book Guildrunner Rawndel|TDCSR|3|Guildrunner Rawndel}.

entries.name: 8. Stone of the Arch Heart
entries: En el corazón de los Paseos del Ensueño hay una columna de diamante puro, tallada con la radiante imagen de un elfo andrógino. Aunque el {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} es adorado en todo el Tal'Dorei como un dios de la magia y el arte, es algo más para el {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} del {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}: un progenitor de su pueblo, una deidad de la paternidad y la maternidad, pero también de ninguna de ellas, un dios liminal que por su propia naturaleza abraza y destruye los binarios. {@book Elves|TDCSR|5|elves} que "nacen del Archicorazón" son honrados en su interior {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, y muchos de los que buscan ese honor vagan por el Barrio del Ensueño en busca de la Piedra, anhelando la transformación física, el poder social o el poder arcano. Algunos buscan durante siglos y nunca la encuentran, pero en tiempos de peligro, el {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} siempre da a conocer su sabiduría a aquellos que realmente la necesitan.

entries.name: Syngorn Adventures
entries: Los Game Masters que ambienten su aventura en {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} pueden utilizar este gancho argumental como inspiración.

entries.name: The River Does Not Run Through It (low-level)
entries: Llegan noticias de los exploradores de Verdant de que el río Feshun ha dejado de desembocar en el mar de Ozmit sin previo aviso. El potente caudal del {@book Tormor Falls|TDCSR|4|Tormor Falls} no muestra signos de disminución del flujo del río, así que el grupo es enviado a investigar, sólo para encontrar un repentino sumidero que ha consumido una pequeña sección del {@book Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse}, haciendo que el río se vierta en esta enorme caverna subterránea. La roca y la tierra que hay debajo parecen estar desmoronándose a un ritmo acelerado, y el aire de abajo huele a descomposición. ¿Cuál podría ser el origen de esta rápida destrucción y cómo se puede remediar?

entries.name: Tormor Falls
entries: Las cataratas de Tormor, que se alimentan de la desembocadura del caudaloso río Feshun que atraviesa el cuerpo del {@book Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse}, son una increíble serie de cascadas de varios niveles que se precipitan por la ladera oriental de la montaña Orencleft a lo largo de cientos de metros. Las cataratas de Tormor, que se hinchan con cada lluvia importante y son hermosas de contemplar en todas las épocas del año, también albergan una serie de cuevas que se esconden bajo la niebla y el rocío, y que conducen más allá del bosque y bajo el {@book Stormcrest Mountains|TDCSR|4|Stormcrest Mountains}.

Un escuadrón de la Guardia Verdant patrulla la base de las cataratas, y muchos han explorado las cavernas en el pasado. Algunos regresan sin nada; otros descubren viejas reliquias y baratijas de los primeros días de Tal'Dorei, o incluso de la época del {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}. Es raro que una patrulla no regrese, pero cuando lo hace, ningún grupo de búsqueda ha podido ponerse en contacto con los supervivientes, o reclamar sus restos. La guardia ha empezado a susurrar que las entradas de las cuevas se mueven, cambiando con cada sol naciente. Las supersticiones que rodean las cuevas de las cataratas de Tormor han crecido tanto que las expediciones que no regresan ya no son buscadas en absoluto, y ninguna patrulla se adentra en las cuevas sin una razón de importancia crítica.

entries.name: Tormor Falls Adventures
entries: Los Game Masters que ambienten su aventura en el {@book Tormor Falls|TDCSR|4|Tormor Falls} pueden utilizar este gancho argumental como inspiración.

entries.name: This Cave Was Made for Me! (mid-level)
entries: Los personajes que viajan por el borde del {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse} escuchan las angustiosas noticias de que la gente de las pequeñas aldeas, e incluso del {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, ha desaparecido en la noche, y ahora, un amigo del grupo se ha unido a las filas de los desaparecidos. Lo que no saben es que estas personas están abandonando el pueblo ellas mismas, atraídas hipnóticamente a las cuevas detrás de {@book Tormor Falls|TDCSR|4|Tormor Falls} por un {@creature aboleth} que vive dentro de un estanque en lo profundo del sistema de cuevas. Los seres que emergen de esas cuevas ya no son humanoides, sino simulacros de vida de pesadilla.

entries.name: Vues'dal Waters

items.name: Scattered Villages:
entries: Población 2.420 (52% {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, 28% {@book goblinkin|TDCSR|5|goblinkin}, 12% {@book lizardfolk|TDCSR|7|lizardfolk}, 5% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 3% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

El volcán conocido como Monte Vues'dal entró en erupción por última vez en los primeros días del {@book Age of Arcanum|TDCSR|2|Age of Arcanum}. Su explosión sacudió la tierra tan terriblemente que la propia montaña fue engullida, creando la cuenca de Vues'dal en el borde del {@book Stormcrest Mountains|TDCSR|4|Stormcrest Mountains}. Hoy en día, la cuenca ha sido completamente rellenada por el río Feshun, y la tierra alrededor de la cuenca de Vues'dal es una de las tierras de cultivo más fértiles del sur de Tal'Dorei. Las aldeas de las Aguas de Vues'dal son conocidas por sus preciados productos, exportando tomates, cerezas, calabazas, lentejas, boniatos y docenas de otros alimentos, tanto básicos como de lujo, a {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} -y desde allí, al resto de Tal'Dorei.

Los habitantes de las Aguas de Vues'dal son en su mayoría {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, pero a lo largo de los años se les han unido algunos de los {@creature lizardfolk} locales que han habitado en las marismas, así como goblinkin que huyen del {@book Iron Authority|TDCSR|4|Tz'Arrm, Helm of the Emperor} al sur. Todas estas personas se han unido para crear algo hermoso alrededor de la caldera de este volcán muerto hace tiempo, y para repeler a los bandidos y monstruos de los pantanos cercanos. Los {@creature lizardfolk} odian luchar contra sus parientes, pero tanto los humanos como los {@creature lizardfolk} bandidos han hecho de los pantanos su hogar, y se aprovechan de estos honestos agricultores desde campamentos que cambian de semana en semana.

entries.name: Vues'dal Adventures
entries: Los Game Masters que ambienten su aventura en las Aguas de Vues'dal pueden utilizar este gancho argumental como inspiración.

entries.name: Legions of the Reptile God (mid-level)
entries: El pueblo de Vues'dal se ha enfrentado sin saberlo a la vanguardia de una fuerza que desea poner de rodillas al {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. La {@creature spirit naga} Maledicta Hexos ha venido desde abajo de la {@book Stormcrest Mountains|TDCSR|4|Stormcrest Mountains} para reunir a la {@creature lizardfolk} tribu en nombre de la {@deity The Cloaked Serpent|Exandria|TDCSR|Cloaked Serpent}. Vues'dal pronto será invadido, y la Guardia Verdant ha pedido {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} ayuda para hacer retroceder a las legiones de este monstruo con delirios de divinidad.

Los ejércitos de Maledicta no sólo contienen incontables {@creature lizardfolk}, sino también varios {@creature hydra|MM|hydras}, y un {@creature night hag} que le sirve de lugarteniente. Maledicta también posee uno de los {@book Astural Scrolls|TDCSR|4|The Astural Scrolls}, un artefacto saqueado de {@book Wrettis|TDCSR|4|Wrettis} {@homebrew |(see page 112)} que le otorga poderes cósmicos asombrosos.

entries.name: Bladeshimmer Shoreline
entries: La costa de Bladeshimmer, llamada así por el lejano brillo del sol a través del Mar de Ozmit, se extiende por la costa central occidental de Tal'Dorei. Esta costa es donde {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, {@book halflings|TDCSR|5|halflings} y {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} pisaron por primera vez el continente de Tal'Dorei, y lleva las marcas de sus primeros pasos en esta tierra. También es el hogar del actual corazón de la República de Tal'Dorei.

El litoral es un centro de comercio internacional, ya que la costa occidental de Tal'Dorei es la más cercana a los continentes de {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra} y {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet}. Cada día, decenas de {@filter ships|vehicles|Vehicle Type=Ship|Source=GoS} mercantes de mástil alto navegan hacia y desde sus tranquilas costas, así como los majestuosos {@item skyship|TDCSR|skyships} que entran y salen a diario de la resplandeciente capital de {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}.

El interior de Bladeshimmer es mayoritariamente una pradera templada, intercalada por ríos frescos y sinuosos. La mayor parte de los productos del oeste de Tal'Dorei proviene de las granjas de esta zona, bendecida con agua limpia y suelo no salino, a pesar de la proximidad del océano. {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} presencia da estabilidad a la región. Sin embargo, los campesinos que viven más allá de las murallas de la ciudad se esfuerzan por defender sus pequeñas parcelas de las madrigueras {@creature ankheg|MM|ankhegs}, los demonios corruptores y los diversos espíritus y monstruos folclóricos que acechan en las sombras de sus mentes.

The Bladeshimmer Shoreline

items.name: Majority Faiths:
entries: {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer}, {@deity The Wildmother|Exandria|TDCSR|Wildmother}, {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon}

items.name: Minority Faiths:
entries: {@deity The Moonweaver|Exandria|TDCSR|Moonweaver}, {@deity The Matron of Ravens|Exandria|TDCSR|Matron of Ravens}, {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather}, {@deity The Lord of the Hells|Exandria|TDCSR|Lord of the Hells}, {@deity The Scaled Tyrant|Exandria|TDCSR|Scaled Tyrant}

items.name: Imports:
entries: Metales preciosos e industriales, madera

items.name: Exports:
entries: Piedra, madera, {@filter ships|vehicles|Vehicle Type=Ship|Source=GoS}, {@creature fish|GoS}, grano, productos, cobalto, {@item gold|PHB}, ganado

entries.name: Daggerbay
entries: Daggerbay, llamada así por el escarpado Arrecife del Sueño que flanquea la bahía, fue donde los primeros colonos humanos de Tal'Dorei tocaron tierra. En esa época pasada, era un bullicioso puerto para la ciudad humana de Puerto {@book O'Noa|TDCSR|4|Ruins of O'Noa (New O'Noa)}. Desde entonces ha caído en desuso tras el {@book Scattered War|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War} y la destrucción del {@book O'Noa|TDCSR|4|Ruins of O'Noa (New O'Noa)}. Siglos después, la bahía no es más que un inquietante recuerdo de días oscuros. Alberga cientos de barcos hundidos y los cuerpos de sus tripulantes perdidos, en las profundidades del arrecife. Los que conocen su historia dicen que las aguas están malditas, y los colonos cercanos difunden rumores de barcos fantasmas y {@creature siren|TftYP|sirens} llaman a los saqueadores a la tumba si se acercan demasiado a las ominosas olas.

entries.name: Daggerbay Adventures
entries: Los Game Masters que ambienten su aventura en {@book Daggerbay|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay} pueden utilizar este gancho argumental como inspiración.

entries.name: Stormbringers (mid-level)
entries: Una sociedad de desterrados {@creature merfolk} ha reclamado {@book Daggerbay|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay} como su dominio. Acosan a cualquier cazador de tesoros que pretenda saquear los restos del fondo de la bahía. Mientras los personajes viajan por las cercanías, una terrible tormenta les obliga a refugiarse en las ruinas de {@book Daggerbay|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay}.

En realidad, la tormenta fue causada por el renegado {@creature merfolk}. Hace unas semanas, descubrieron una reliquia del {@deity The Stormlord|Exandria|TDCSR|Stormlord} con el poder de convocar y dirigir tormentas. La costa está ahora envuelta en una vorágine interminable. Esa noche, cuando los personajes se refugian en las ruinas, son asaltados por los {@creature merfolk|MM|merfolks'} matones humanoides que habitan la tierra. Estos brutos intentan capturar a los personajes y entregarlos a sus líderes.

entries.name: Daggerbay Mountains
entries: Las páginas de la historia no recuerdan al Titán Fundido, ni cuándo esta feroz entidad de metal líquido fue abatida por el {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} primordial al final del {@book Founding|TDCSR|2|The Founding}. La entidad quedó sellada en su interior y fue consumida por la tierra, dando lugar a una cadena de montañas que ha permanecido en pie desde entonces. Alcanzando la frontera noroeste del {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse} y extendiéndose hasta el Mar de Ozmit, estos picos tormentosos funcionaron como la primera frontera entre el {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} establecido desde hace tiempo y las florecientes colonias humanas de Tal'Dorei durante su llegada.

Durante la mayor parte de la historia, el {@book Daggerbay Mountains|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay Mountains}, o los lyren'alsi en élfico, eran conocidos por ser desolados y carentes de valor material. Los exploradores del {@book O'Noa|TDCSR|4|Ruins of O'Noa (New O'Noa)} volvían a casa con las manos vacías, si es que volvían. Los supervivientes volvían con historias de bandas de gigantes sedientos de sangre y de un solo ojo que vagaban por las cumbres: {@creature cyclops|MM|cyclopes}. {@book Issylran|TDCSR|4|Issylra} colonos y {@book Syngornian|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} aprendieron a dejar a los lyren'alsi en paz.

Décadas más tarde, el {@book Emerald Outpost|TDCSR|4|Emerald Outpost} se estableció como un importante puesto comercial para los pueblos de {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} y {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. Con un asentamiento tan valioso en las cercanías, las peligrosas cumbres del {@book Daggerbay's|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay Mountains} despertaron de repente el interés de aventureros y buscadores de fortuna. Las pequeñas búsquedas de riquezas por descubrir se convirtieron en vastas expediciones. Estas incursiones en las montañas agravaron a sus habitantes territoriales; los exploradores elfos informaron de {@creature cyclops} asaltantes y {@creature cyclops stormcaller|TDCSR|cyclops stormcallers} que realizaban extraños rituales entre los ojos de las tormentas eléctricas por la noche, y de {@creature bulette|MM|bulettes} hambrientos que cazaban más allá de su dominio normal, como si fueran guiados por alguna inteligencia desconocida.

entries.name: Daggerbay Mountains Adventures
entries: Los Game Masters que ambienten su aventura en el {@book Daggerbay Mountains|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay Mountains} pueden utilizar estos ganchos argumentales como inspiración.

entries.name: Eye of the Storm (mid-level)
entries: Los grupos de {@creature hill giant|MM|hill giants} están emigrando a las montañas, dejando sus asentamientos al pie de la colina vacíos de guerreros, civiles y enfermos por igual. Un medio-elfo {@creature scout} llamado Thunderchaser ha causado un gran revuelo en el {@book Emerald Outpost|TDCSR|4|Emerald Outpost} al traer el cadáver carbonizado por un rayo de un {@creature hill giant} con un ojo arrancado ritualmente. ¿Qué planean los {@creature cyclops stormcaller|TDCSR|cyclops stormcallers} {@homebrew |(see page 235)} bajo las ocultas nubes de tormenta del {@book Daggerbay Mountains|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay Mountains}?

entries.name: A Metal of Memory (high-level)
entries: La antigua bestia fundida que se hundió bajo estos picos rocosos dejó tras de sí bolsas, situadas muy por debajo de la superficie, de un metal increíblemente raro con propiedades misteriosas, llamado orichalcum. El repentino descubrimiento ha provocado el frenesí de los empresarios locales, y la consiguiente fiebre ya ha desatado la violencia entre las bandas de cazadores de tesoros. A medida que los aventureros cavan más profundo, descubren que una esencia de la antigua criatura aún vive, y busca venganza.

entries.name: Emerald Outpost

items.name: Town:
entries: Población 1.470 (76% {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, 19% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 3% {@book halflings|TDCSR|5|halflings}, 2% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

Originalmente establecido por el {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} de {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} como un puesto de avanzada oculto para proteger su patria del creciente imperio de {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig}, el {@book Emerald Outpost|TDCSR|4|Emerald Outpost} cayó en desuso después del {@book Scattered War|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War}. Este antiguo puesto militar es ahora un puesto comercial intermedio y un lugar de descanso para los mercaderes que viajan entre el {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} y el {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}. Las Cámaras Esmeralda, utilizadas en su día como sala de guerra, y más recientemente como cámara diplomática para los gobiernos aliados de {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} y {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, se han convertido estos días en un elegante bazar, en el que los comerciantes de {@book Emonian|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} y {@book Syngornian|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} pueden vender sus mercancías sin tener que hacer el viaje completo a ninguna de las dos ciudades.

entries.name: Emon, the City of Fellowship

items.name: Metropolis:
entries: Población 365.026 (63% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 8% {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, 7% {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, 22% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

{@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} se alza desafiante contra todos los que amenazan a Tal'Dorei y a su pueblo. Es el corazón cultural y político de la República de Tal'Dorei, así como un nexo de comercio, entretenimiento, viajes, educación y aventura.

{@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} es accesible sólo a través de sus puertas fuertemente patrulladas y por {@item skyship|TDCSR}. Los habitantes de la ciudad suelen estar bien protegidos de los atacantes externos y de los asedios.

entries.name: Government
entries: {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} es la sede del {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council}, el máximo órgano de gobierno de la nación. Aunque el consejo originalmente servía bajo el Soberano de Tal'Dorei, el último soberano de la nación fue asesinado cuando el {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} atacó el {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. Tras la muerte del {@book Thordak the Cinder King|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} y el resto del {@book Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}, el {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} fue reconstruido y el consejo reformado como columna vertebral de la nueva República de Tal'Dorei. El consejo y sus miembros son {@book described in detail starting on page 42.|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council}

Una consecuencia no deseada de depender de la magia para reconstruir rápidamente {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} es que los magos de Tal'Dorei tienen ahora una increíble influencia sobre el incipiente consejo. Algunos temen que, sin un soberano, el consejo sea incapaz de mantener a raya a los arcanistas y Tal'Dorei se disuelva en una magocracia.

entries.name: Current Events
entries: El {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} es más conocido por sus políticas que afectan a todo Tal'Dorei. A menudo se ignora que el consejo también gobierna {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} y resuelve los asuntos cotidianos de la ciudad. Estos son algunos de los acontecimientos actuales, tanto grandes como pequeños, que afectan a {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} en la actualidad; estos temas pueden añadir sabor a las discusiones y rumores que los personajes escuchan por la ciudad, e incluso podrían inspirarles nuevas aventuras.

entries.name: Elemental Disturbances
entries: Han pasado más de veinte años desde que {@book Thordak the Cinder King|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} fue asesinado en las cavernas bajo {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. Sus restos en el {@book Cloudtop District|TDCSR|4|Cloudtop District}, así como en el {@book Scar of the Cinder King|TDCSR|4|Scar of the Cinder King}, una franja de destrucción elemental fuera de las murallas de la ciudad, han sido atendidos por miembros del {@book Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari} Fuego, curando gradualmente las persistentes heridas de su influencia. Sin embargo, los fuegos primordiales que se filtraron de su cuerpo siguen persistiendo en las cavernas bajo la ciudad donde murió. Cada uno o dos años, una incursión de fuego salvaje y odioso {@creature cinderslag elemental|TDCSR|cinderslag elementals} {@homebrew |(see page 231)} irrumpe en las calles de la ciudad, causando un caos masivo, costosos daños y batallas a vida o muerte para la guardia de la ciudad.

entries.name: Mercenary Mages
entries: Hace una generación, la incipiente {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles} contrató a cientos, si no miles, de magos mercenarios para ayudar en la reconstrucción de {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} y otras ciudades de Tal'Dorei. Hoy en día, Tal'Dorei está reconstruida, y los pocos problemas de infraestructura no son suficientes para emplear a todos los mercenarios que dejó la liga. Estos mercenarios sin trabajo ahora merodean por bares de mala muerte y causan problemas a los lugareños. La mayoría de la gente preferiría que se fueran, pero es difícil no sentir pena por su situación.

entries.name: Walls and Slums
entries: The city's outer walls have fallen under heavy criticism from politicians and civilians alike in recent years. Many people are concerned that the walls' true purpose these days is to separate the slums outside the walls from the "respectable" districts within them. Popular opinion is now that the great {@book City of Fellowship|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} should do more to help its less fortunate, but council politicians continue to stall. In private, Master of Commerce {@creature Vex'ahlia|TDCSR} de Rolo fumes that she wants to help, but can't cut through political red tape with her {@item Fenthras|TDCSR|legendary bow} and arrow.

entries.name: Society
entries: While in antiquity {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} was the heart of a human empire, the city has grown to encompass people from all over Tal'Dorei, and all over the world. Its citizens include people of nearly all known races from Exandria's many nations, thriving on the new innovations and ideas of its citizenry. It has been this way since the sovereignty of {@book Zan Tal'Dorei|TDCSR|2|Tal'Dorei Ascendant}, when the alliances she formed invited dozens of displaced {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs}, and {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants} into her city. Since then, {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} has developed into a city whose people valued innovation and collaboration, especially in small, cohesive groups—virtues that some historians within the {@book Alabaster Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} believe have given rise to the prominence of the modern adventuring party.

While {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} is becoming more commercial and the use of {@item gold|PHB} as currency has been ubiquitous throughout Tal'Dorei's history, many communities within the city are still close-knit enough to use the barter system. During the reign of {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig}, the {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans} of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} adopted a dwarven oath called rudraz, an intimate promise between two people to repay a deed or trade. Though the rudraz is not a contract, the {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} believed that an oathbreaker would be forever barred from passing beyond the Brightguard Gates of Hilmaire, the gates that allow {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} to pass to the afterlife. {@book Humans|TDCSR|5|humans} in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} treat the rudraz more lightly, often using it to seal matters of business or politics rather than personal promises, but breaking this oath still carries massive social repercussions. Few look kindly upon a person with the epithet "Oathbreaker".

entries.name: Rebirth
entries: {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} has mostly recovered from its destruction at the talons of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} and {@book Thordak's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} subsequent occupation. A number of Tal'Dorei's most significant factions played a role in {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} rebirth, and their members enjoy positions of prominence throughout the city. {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} was rapidly rebuilt to its former glory, due to the expensive but effective intervention of mercenary mages serving the {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles}. Thanks also to the {@book Clasp's|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} underground networks and established hierarchies, {@book Emonian|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} society and culture was able to bounce back more swiftly than any other major settlement in Tal'Dorei.

And the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council}, formerly an advisory council to the sovereign, is now the ruling council of the land. Folk heroes and career politicians alike sit on the council. Over the past two decades, the council has, with many missteps, enacted the will of the people—allowing Tal'Dorei to transition from a monarchical power to a republic without war or insurrection.

However, the swiftness of {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} rebirth has put the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} in a precarious position. Not only are they socially indebted to a criminal faction—one whose members now command immense celebrity among the common folk—the council now owes vast amounts of gold to mages of the {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles}. League conjurers created thousands of tons of stone and steel, and each one of their transmuters rebuilt everything from taverns to townhouses and sewers to stately manors as quickly as a hundred laborers. {@book Thordak's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} hoard of plundered wealth has dwindled to nothing, repaying the league, and they have done the same in cities across the land. Some members of the council have already caved to pressure from factions within the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} and the {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles}, and subsequently turn a blind eye to the crime and magical abuse that run rampant throughout the city. Barely a single human generation old, the young republic is already struggling under the weight of ruling in a just and noble manner.

entries.name: Defenses
entries: The Republic of Tal'Dorei has no standing army, and doesn't elect a Master of War—a military commander-in-chief—to its council outside of wartime. In peacetime, the Master of Defense is responsible for the acquisition of mercenaries and adventurers for tasks which require the use of force. They also have the ability to conscript existing militias and town guards into military service and call them to {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} defense at any time, though typically only while the Master of War is being elected.

The only standing forces pledged exclusively to the defense of the realm are the elite forces of {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio}. Mobilizing the armies of {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} to {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} aid generally requires the city to withstand a week-long siege. However, in case of internal strife, there are stables positioned every fifteen miles along the Othen Trail, allowing Daxio's legendary outriders to arrive at {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} in a mere two days' time by switching out their exhausted steeds.

{@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} is encircled by 60-foot-high stone walls that stretch from the eastern fields to the western shore—though a number of discussions in the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} have revolved around the strategic irrelevance of great stone walls. They didn't protect {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} against the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} over twenty years ago, and they wouldn't have done much against an army of {@creature cultist|MM|cultists} and winged {@creature gloomstalker|EGW|gloomstalkers} had {@deity The Whispered One|Exandria|TDCSR} led an army against Tal'Dorei. As {@item skyship|TDCSR|skyships} grow more popular and affordable around the world, even the council's Master of Defense is considering demolishing the city's walls—making the strange case that such fortifications are prized more for their historic and cultural value than for their strategic importance.

These walls are patrolled by lightly armed and armored members of the Arms of Emon, the city's official watch and constabulary. They are divided unofficially into the Arms upon the Wall and the Arms on the Streets, the latter of which are assigned to patrol the city streets to dissuade petty criminals and respond to violent crime.

entries.name: Crime
entries: Hundreds of miles of tunnels of varied provenance run beneath {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. Most are the forgotten remnants of paved-over neighborhoods and secret passageways made by thieves' guilds during the reign of {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig}. Others are the lairs of tunneling monsters. The origins of others still are lost forever, for they have already long since been turned into sewer passages to whisk away the refuse of {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} citizens.

The vast majority of the tunnels closer to the surface are known to the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} and used to rapidly move about the city unseen. Somewhere deep in this network of unlabeled roads is the {@book Clasp's|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} secret headquarters, where all manner of thieves, {@creature clasp cutthroat|TDCSR|cutthroats}, fences, and spies gather beneath their banner. Though the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} operates in major cities across Tal'Dorei, {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} has always been their home, and saving their neighbors from {@book Thordak's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} reign of terror gave the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} the dubious benefit of a heroic reputation.

However, the {@book Myriad|TDCSR|3|The Myriad} crime syndicate from {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount} has spent over two decades relentlessly clawing their way into the {@book Clasp's|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} territory across Tal'Dorei—dismantling their networks, poaching their clients, and assassinating their informants. The {@book Myriad|TDCSR|3|The Myriad} hasn't managed to completely eliminate the {@book Clasp's|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} hold in any of the cities they've targeted, but that hasn't stopped them from bringing the ongoing power struggle to the {@book Clasp's|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} doorstep. {@book Myriad|TDCSR|3|The Myriad} agents bargain in shadowed alleys, gamble in upscale taverns, and lurk in the very tunnels that the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} relies on, waiting for their chance to unseat the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} once and for all.

entries.name: Geography and Climate
entries: {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} is not a tourist destination for its climate—the city is known for sudden, pounding rainstorms just as much as for its beautiful, sunny days. The city is blessed with cool summers and warm winters, thanks to its proximity to the cool Ozmit Sea. Though snow rarely falls on the city itself, it relies on springtime snowmelt from the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} to fill its reservoirs throughout the year.
{@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} is made up of the following districts:

entries.name: Abdar's Promenade
entries: The Promenade is an open marketplace district and massive bazaar that dominates eastern {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, named for the legendary spicemonger from {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet} who helped fund the construction of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. To this day, the name of Abdar is synonymous with both generosity and business savvy. Nearly everything a person could want can be found within the tents, carts, warehouses, and shops of the promenade. Its intertwining roads stretch for miles, and it has dozens of tiny neighborhoods, each with their own distinct cultures and identities. The promenade is heavily patrolled by the Arms of Emon, for its sunny reputation is shrouded by an equally significant reputation for literal back-alley criminal deals.

entries.name: Central District
entries: This is the largest residential district within {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} walls. It houses most of the city's merchant class, including traveling traders, ship captains, and guild journeymen. The Central District is a patchwork of thousands of personal homes, tenements, and guildhalls of all shapes and sizes, peppered with small taverns and inns on nearly every street corner.

These neighborhoods lay clustered together among tightly set streets, occasionally broken up by park grasses or the Ozmit Waterways that snake through the region between the promenade and the port. Visitors to the Central District are advised not to go out at night; the wide disparity of wealth from home to home here has seen a recent rise in crime, and the city watch seems reluctant to find a constructive solution. Residents who know the lay of the land have an easier time at night and can help visitors avoid the most dangerous streets.

entries.name: Cloudtop District
entries: Out of all of {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} districts, the Cloudtop has, in some ways, changed the most over the decades. In {@book Drassig's|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} time, a monstrous fortress loomed over the manors of his sycophants. In the age of {@book Zan Tal'Dorei's|TDCSR|2|Tal'Dorei Ascendant} descendants, countless mages transfigured that decadent citadel into a sleek, elegant palace. By the time the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} came, decadence had once more crept up on {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, and though the Palace of the Sovereign remained much the same, the Cloudtop District was once again a nest of luxury and the throne of the social elite. The latest additions in that era were {@item skyship|TDCSR} platforms, so that the wealthiest and most connected in Tal'Dorei could travel in exclusive luxury—soaring through the skies rather than enduring arduous journeys over land or sea.

All of that was reduced to slag by the advent of the {@book Cinder King|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King}. {@book Thordak|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} made the Cloudtop District his home, and the palace itself his throne. His very presence caused magma to surge from the caverns beneath {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, where previously no fires burned. {@book Thordak|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} ruled there for only a matter of months, but those few months were enough to annihilate unknown millions of gold pieces' worth of art and creations of untold value—though the greedy dragon took care to command his minions to save the most beautiful works for his treasure hoard.

Today, the Cloudtop District is rebuilt, though the most stubborn elemental influences of the {@book Cinder King|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} linger in {@book Thordak's Crater|TDCSR|4|7. Thordak's Crater}. A new castle called {@book Cloudwatch Palace|TDCSR|4|6. Cloudwatch Palace} has been built atop the city of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, and it contains the chambers of the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council}, as well as grand dining halls and guest quarters for visiting dignitaries. Much of the castle is a museum, displaying what regalia and objets d'art survived the wrath of the {@book Cinder King|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King}. The private chambers of the palace also contain a number of {@spell teleportation circle|PHB|teleportation circles} that leading councilmembers can use to return to their homes at night—particularly if they live in far-off cities such as {@book Whitestone|TDCSR|4|Whitestone}.

entries.name: Temple District
entries: Some say that this northern district contains more temples than in the rest of Tal'Dorei's cities combined. This is a flagrant exaggeration, but at first glance, most people believe it. {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} is a city of many people, from many different places, with many different faiths. Even folk who worship the same gods worship them differently, and have built their own temples. Legend has it that shrines and temples used to be built all across {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} (and there are still some small sanctuaries elsewhere in the city), but a cleric of the {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather} declared her temple the greatest in all {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. Her boast was met with scorn from a nearby church of the {@deity The Stormlord|Exandria|TDCSR|Stormlord}. Their clerics, always eager to rise to a challenge, built an even greater temple across the street, and soon, people of all faiths were building the most magnificent structures they could, all in one tiny corner of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}.

Today, cathedrals to the {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer} and the {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon} stand at apex among smaller temples to the {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather}, the {@deity The Stormlord|Exandria|TDCSR|Stormlord}, the {@deity The Wildmother|Exandria|TDCSR|Wildmother}, and the {@deity The Matron of Ravens|Exandria|TDCSR|Matron of Ravens}. All {@book Prime Deities|TDCSR|3|Prime Deities} have at least a moderately sized house of worship here, and even some of the {@book Betrayer Gods|TDCSR|3|Betrayer Gods} are worshiped in secrecy.

Anyone who seeks shelter here, be they rich or poor, can find sanctuary in the Temple District. Even the faithful of gods of strength, such as the {@deity The Stormlord|Exandria|TDCSR|Stormlord} and the {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon}, have mercy for those who need the aid of others to help them stand on their own.

Travelers and sailors come to leave tokens and gifts at shrines to bless their journeys, while people of all walks of life seek the graces of the {@deity The Changebringer|Exandria|TDCSR|Changebringer} before undertaking risky endeavors. The meek search for wisdom in the great halls of the {@deity The Knowing Mentor|Exandria|TDCSR|Knowing Mentor}, as the artists and wistful folk give praise to the {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart}. However, not all folk are drawn toward religion, nor trusting of it, and temples past have been exposed as frauds—or worse, cults who venerate power.

Recently, an off-kilter faith to a lesser idol called the {@deity The Traveler|Exandria|TDCSR|Traveler} has found purchase in the Temple Ward—primarily in the form of puerile graffiti in back alleys. Other quasi-religious spiritual entities have small cult followings in the Temple Ward. They are generally allowed to flourish to whatever degree they can, so long as their beliefs don't advocate for any behavior that would break the laws of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}.

entries.name: Erudite Quarter
entries: This district is home to members of the educated upper-middle class and destitute academics alike. Several institutions of higher learning have their stately campuses here, ranging from well-to-do boarding schools to Tal'Dorei's most premiere academic and arcane institutions.

Beautiful towers in ancient {@book Syngornian|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} style stretch to the sky across a cityscape of centuries-old halls of learning and student boardinghouses. Here, the finest schools and colleges draw the wealthy, the gifted, and the brilliant—and none more so than the {@book Alabaster Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum}, often lauded as the largest and most accomplished institute of arcane study on the continent. Though the district's walls were shattered and its libraries crushed during the invasion of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}, the Erudite Quarter has thankfully been mostly reconstructed, thanks to the efforts of the {@book Lyceum's|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} staff and students.

Members of the {@book Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum}, under the direction of Headmaster Thurmond Adlam, performed the reconstruction themselves not simply because they sought to project an image of good work ethic and self-sufficiency, but because the heads of their colleges distrust the {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles}. Their motives and sources of funding are, in the eyes of the {@book Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum}, too opaque to be trusted. Their suspicion has often been derided either as elitism over the diverse array of mercenary mages the league hires, or as sour grapes over losing out on countless lucrative reconstruction contracts.

entries.name: Military District
entries: Since {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} has no standing army, the Military District is one of the city's smallest wards. Nevertheless, it has the capacity to house and train a vast number of soldiers if an army needs to be levied from the people of Tal'Dorei. The Military District is mostly filled with several prisons and jails, including the infamous {@book Black Bastille|TDCSR|4|11. The Black Bastille}, as well as tightly locked barracks and instructional facilities for the Arms of Emon.

entries.name: Cemetery District
entries: This smaller section of the city is filled with graveyards and small religious sanctuaries so that people with means to purchase a gravesite or a mausoleum can bury their dead in whatever luxury they can afford. Countless gravestones line the rolling hills of the district. They are sectioned off from the roads by tall iron fences, with mausoleums of more affluent families dotting the grassy hillsides. As surface space grew limited in centuries past, the city excavated a network of catacombs called the Undervaults. Upkeep, expansion, and general safeguarding of the sites are all overseen by the Gravewatchers, a guild of gravekeepers that have held political and social hegemony over the district for generations.

Their attempts to expand the Undervaults have had mixed results over the centuries. Most new excavations meet without incident (likely because the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} has learned to keep their tunnels far from this district). However, excavations in recent decades have broken into the {@book Crystalfen Caverns|TDCSR|4|Crystalfen Caverns}, an eerie cave system filled with mind-bending inscriptions and horrific beings. The breach was promptly sealed off.

Yet the sealing of the caverns did not stop some members of the Gravewatchers from seeing an opportunity to gain fame and glory. Most who ventured into the caverns were never seen again, and those who have returned shudder unspeakably of the horrors they escaped. Still, passage is occasionally granted to the {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} or adventurers willing to pay the Gravewatchers for entry to the dangerous realm below.

entries.name: Port of Emon
entries: {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} is bordered on the west by the Ozmit Sea and is generally sheltered from the worst of its storms. The vast {@book Port of Emon|TDCSR|4|Port of Emon} allows hundreds of thousands of gold pieces' worth of goods to flow through the city every single day. Well over a hundred ships fill this port at any given time, and the dock crews are ever working, carrying crates and goods away to {@book Abdar's Promenade|TDCSR|4|Abdar's Promenade}, or to empty vessels for exportation. The northern sector of the Port is mostly allocated to the Everline, a powerful fisherfolk's guild. They frequently feud with the Onyx Banner, {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} most powerful shipping guild, over which docks they are permitted to use. Both guilds keep their hands clean, but it's an open secret that both hire adventurers and mercenaries to trash the other's ships and warehouses to intimidate them. Adventurers in need of fast cash who don't mind dodging the Arms of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} can find good work as muscle for either of these two guilds.

entries.title: Art Credit: {@link Kent Davis|http://artstation.com/idrawbagman}
entries.altText: The Port of Emon where several ships on the water approach the gleaming, colorful city in the distance. A beautiful, tall castle stands far in the background, overlooking the city.

entries.name: Outwall
entries: During the reign of {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig}, a massive city of tents and hovels grew outside of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, filled with those too poor to pay {@book Drassig's|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} extortative taxes. By the end of the {@book Scattered War|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War}, the slum had grown to a third of the city's size, and nearly half its population. Even during the reign of {@book Zan Tal'Dorei|TDCSR|2|Tal'Dorei Ascendant}, these slums continued to grow, as refugees of the {@book Scattered War|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War} tried to earn enough money to find stability within {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} walls.

Though their conditions were still meager when the magnanimous {@book Zan Tal'Dorei|TDCSR|2|Tal'Dorei Ascendant} ended {@book Drassig's|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} iron rule, the city's denizens chose to remain, having created a community with its own culture of inexpensive living and brotherhood in poverty, away from the bustle of the city's inner streets. A microcosm of {@book Emonian|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} society now exists within the city of Outwall, including its own trade square, shrines for worship, and makeshift farms on the outskirts. As early as two decades ago, Outwall was called the Upper Slums—a derogatory name given to it by {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} Cloudtop elite. People within Outwall tried to transform the term "Upper Slums" into a symbol of civic pride, but it never stuck. The name Outwall eventually emerged after community leaders demanded an audience with the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} in an event that came to be called the Outer Wall Debates—for they demanded the council convene in the slums' own town square.

These days, Outwall is becoming a trendy place to live, thanks to its vibrant culture and relatively inexpensive housing. Its locals are fighting hard to keep young people with money to burn from the {@book Central District|TDCSR|4|Central District} from gentrifying their home. It hasn't come to violence yet, but the angrier members of the Outwall community clandestinely meet with adventurers to burn down the stylish houses and mansions that are driving out local residents and businesses.

entries.name: Southgate Farms
entries: Inspired by the civic action of the people of {@book Outwall|TDCSR|4|Outwall}, the farmers of Southgate were able to break from the ugly name of "slum" in the past decade. This community of farmers and ranchers, formerly known as the Lower Slum, exists outside {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} southern gates. It first formed when a large refugee band from {@book Othanzia|TDCSR|4|Issylra} was barred entry into the city in the midst of the {@book Scattered War|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War}. Instead of dispersing, they decided to lay down roots while {@book Drassig's|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} armies were out fighting a losing battle against {@book Zan Tal'Dorei|TDCSR|2|Tal'Dorei Ascendant}. These squatters eventually formed a community of farmers who petitioned {@book Zan Tal'Dorei|TDCSR|2|Tal'Dorei Ascendant} for land in exchange for providing produce and grown goods to the people of the city.

Thanks to the aid of the First Sovereign, the descendants of those {@book Othanzian|TDCSR|4|Issylra} refugees have become one of the most significant sources of fresh food for the people of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. Frustrated by being saddled with the name of "slum," and inspired by the Outer Wall Debates, the leading families of the Lower Slums demanded recognition by the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} as well. They were met with little debate, and these humble farmers are now a respectable part of {@book Emonian|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} society—even if they live outside the city's defensive walls.

This southern region of the city is also home to a famous site of modern history: Greyskull Keep, the former base of operations for Vox Machina in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. This fortress was gifted to them by the Last Sovereign as thanks for saving his life. The various heroes of Vox Machina have moved on to other homes (and now typically gather in {@book Whitestone|TDCSR|4|Whitestone} for holidays), and they allowed the keep to be turned into a museum of their heroic exploits.

entries.name: Shoreline Farms
entries: Less respectable than the {@book Southgate Farms|TDCSR|4|Southgate Farms} are the communities along a stretch of murky shore north of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. These people of {@book Outwall|TDCSR|4|Outwall} have tried for decades to turn terrible, salty land into effective farmland, to mixed results. They have successfully cultivated the few vegetables that grow in saltwater-soaked soil, leading to bountiful harvests of savory quattet gourds and the hard-to-grow brineroot. However, the farms' distance from the city gives them little protection from dangers that city folk think little of. Adventurers are always wanted to protect the farms from petty criminals and wandering monsters, but the farmers have little to pay. Generally, only utterly novice adventurers find their start in a place like the Shoreline Farms—but all heroes have to start somewhere.

entries.name: The Grotto
entries: This sprawling series of underground chambers composes the {@book Clasp's|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} headquarters beneath the city of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. It's rumored that over a dozen entrances to the Grotto are concealed amidst the labyrinthine tunnels, which are both naturally occurring and a part of {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} sewers. That doesn't even begin to get into the hundreds of other entrances and access shafts abandoned and filled in for fear of discovery. The very nature of the {@book Clasp's|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} business is to keep shifting out of sight, and as such, the actual core of the organization moves from base to base between multiple subterranean structures, ever building further underground, or repurposing a long-abandoned hideout whenever necessary.

entries.name: Points of Interest
entries: A number of both popular and historically significant landmarks can be found in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. They are keyed to the map of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}.

entries.title: Emon, The City of Fellowship
entries.altText: A map of Emon: The City of Fellowship along the Ozmit Sea coastline, detailing the city's many districts, with the port on the Ozmit Sea to the west and its castle directly in the middle of the city. Channels and waterways wind throughout the city, circling towards the north.

entries: {@note Art Credit: {@link Andy Law|http://artstation.com/andylaw1}}

entries.name: 1. Laughing Lamia Inn
entries: While the city is home to countless taverns and inns for the weary traveler or practiced performer, few are as grand and well known as the Laughing Lamia. Almost as old as the city itself, this fine establishment has traded hands numerous times over the years, and has expanded with each transition, leaving the massive, four-story institution a hodgepodge mass of odd rooms and themes, all centered around a raucous central tavern room filled with dozens of tables. Currently under the ownership of a brash and cheerful lass called Luthania Wells, this hot spot for traveling traders and adventurers alike rarely sees an hour in the day (or night) where there isn't something interesting going on within.

entries.name: 2. Azalea Street Park
entries: Azalea Street, within {@book Abdar's Promenade|TDCSR|4|Abdar's Promenade}, is one of {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} oldest neighborhoods, and is full to bursting with small businesses, quaint homes, and hole-in-the-wall restaurants, such as the {@book Laughing Lamia|TDCSR|4|1. Laughing Lamia Inn}. Amidst the chaos of daily life, Azalea Street is also home to a peaceful park overlooking the Ozmit Waterways. When the stress of constant battles becomes too much to bear, adventurers in the know take a moment to visit the Azalea Street Park and recover, maybe even swapping stories with other relaxing heroes. Legend has it that heroes who meditate among the flowers and drink in the sea air return invigorated by the spirit of the {@deity The Wildmother|Exandria|TDCSR|Wildmother}. A statue of the {@deity The Wildmother|Exandria|TDCSR|Wildmother} and {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer} dancing together graces a fountain in the center of the park. Once per week, a character can gain {@variantrule inspiration|PHB} ({@variantrule inspiration|DMG|as described in the fifth edition rules}) by taking a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short rest} in Azalea Street Park.

entries.name: 3. Anvilgate
entries: Made of stark black stone and adorned with intricate brass metalwork, this grand blacksmithy is one of the most striking buildings in {@book Abdar's Promenade|TDCSR|4|Abdar's Promenade}. Decades ago, a restless craftsman from {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} of the name Grahf Tiltkettle grew weary of solitary pursuits and worried that interest in blacksmithing would give way to the emerging trend of mass-production. Tiltkettle retired in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} and dedicated his respectable fortune to ignite the spark of inspiration in those who wished to learn the ways of the hammer and anvil, hoping to instill the joy of the {@deity The All-Hammer|Exandria|TDCSR|All-Hammer} in a new generation. He funded the creation of Anvilgate, a massive, public blacksmithy where any folk who wished to try their hand at the smithing of metals could do so under the {@deity The All-Hammer|Exandria|TDCSR|All-Hammer's} guidance.

Cheaper ores and materials were often donated by friends of Tiltkettle to aid the volunteer mentors in teaching their craft to the less fortunate, while folks who wished to bring their own ingots were welcome to do so. The location has become popular enough to begin expanding its facility to include kilns for ceramics and looms for weaving. While the tools are open for anyone to use on the premises, all are warned of the curse that will beset any wanton thief who steals from under the {@deity The All-Hammer|Exandria|TDCSR|All-Hammer's} gaze.

entries.name: 4. Traverse Junction
entries: The most magically active structure in Tal'Dorei shines like a pyramid of pure sapphire in the bustling center of the {@book Erudite Quarter|TDCSR|4|Erudite Quarter}, its walls thrumming with arcane energy. It is the Traverse Junction, and all visitors to the {@book Erudite Quarter|TDCSR|4|Erudite Quarter} stop to see it when they visit.

In nearly every major Exandrian city, there are {@spell teleportation circle|PHB|teleportation circles} that link mages to other such {@spell teleportation circle|PHB|circles} around the world. Each and every one of these major {@spell teleportation circle|PHB|circles} has a twin in the Traverse Junction, a travel nexus for approved mages and world leaders. Any characters renowned in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} or honored by the {@book Alabaster Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} may make use of the Junction (for 50 gp, if they can't cast {@spell teleportation circle}), allowing them to travel to major cities such as {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}, {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, and {@book Whitestone|TDCSR|4|Whitestone} in Tal'Dorei; Port Damali and Rexxentrum in {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount}; {@book Ank'Harel|TDCSR|4|Marquet} in {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet}; and Vasselheim in {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra}.

The telemagi who curate the {@spell teleportation circle|PHB|circles} are always in search of new teleportation sigils to different lands; they are willing to pay a handsome sum for the services of powerful and magically skilled adventurers willing to seek out and catalog new circle sigils for their records.

entries.name: 5. Alabaster Lyceum
entries: The gleaming white halls and elaborate gardens of the {@book Alabaster Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} signal to all who see them that they gaze upon the greatest institute of higher learning in Tal'Dorei—though numerous scholars in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} and {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} would heatedly dispute that claim. Regardless, this place is the heart of homegrown academia in the Republic of Tal'Dorei, boldly striving to make a name for itself alongside the ancient scholarly traditions of {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra}, {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet}, and {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount}. The {@book Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} (for those who can afford the impressive tuition) is an unparalleled center for study and research of history, economics, alchemy, art, and—most of all—magic and the arcane. Many of Tal'Dorei's greatest scholars and bards paid their dues in these halls, and the history of the {@book Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} and its graduates are featured in all manner of superstitions and folktales.

entries.name: 6. Cloudwatch Palace
entries: In the wake of the {@book Chroma Conclave's|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} destruction of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, the towering palace that stood as home to the sovereign and the center of governance within the city fell to fire and ruin. In the decades since, construction began with the aid of the {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles} to construct a new palace to help house the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} and be a symbolic center for all major political affairs within the region. The Cloudwatch Palace now sits atop the once-smoldering hill where {@book Thordak|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} once claimed his roost, a symbol of {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} enduring will and optimistic hope for the future. Within these high-arched halls, countless chambers hold space for diplomats, meetings, and in the case of holidays, grandiose celebrations that draw the attention of powerful figures all across Exandria.

entries.name: 7. Thordak's Crater
entries: One last unsettling element of the {@book Cloudtop District|TDCSR|4|Cloudtop District} is the elementally scarred remains of {@book Thordak's Crater|TDCSR|4|7. Thordak's Crater}. Even after two decades of healing from {@book the Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari} of Pyrah, {@book Thordak's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} fires still burn beneath the Cloudtop. The smoldering entrance to the caverns remains cordoned off from the public because of its unsightly appearance and sulfurous stench, and because fiery creatures occasionally try to claw their way out into the fresh air. The crater is often forgotten, but every few months an adventuring party makes their way inside to seek treasure or glory within the volatile caverns—and such expeditions are a favorite topic of conversation (and clandestine betting) among the politicians, political aides, remaining city nobility, and nouveau riche of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}.

Why {@book Thordak's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} magic lingers enough to create these mindless {@creature cinderslag elemental|TDCSR|cinderslag elementals} {@homebrew |(see page 231)} is a mystery; but it seems to be limited to the crater, as the elementals cannot go beyond it without collapsing into inert slurry.

entries.name: 8. Emon Skyport
entries: This elevated port is complete with docking platforms solely for the use of skyfaring vessels. The original {@book Emon Skyport|TDCSR|4|8. Emon Skyport} was the first of its kind in Tal'Dorei, and its successor is every bit as revolutionary as the original.

The {@book Emon Skyport|TDCSR|4|8. Emon Skyport} was destroyed when the {@book Cinder King|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} claimed the {@book Cloudtop District|TDCSR|4|Cloudtop District} as his fiery throne, but like so much of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, it has since been rebuilt.
